item.title: Wolf Hall - Hilary Mantel (2009)
item.description: Wolf Hall - Hilary Mantel (2009) The conflict at the heart of the novel hand is very simple, the king needed a male heir and his wife of 20 years Katherine was too old to have more children. His closest and highest ranking advisor, the Cardinal Thomas Wolsey fell out of favour due to his inability to procure the divorce from the Pope in the Vatican. Enter Thomas Cromwell, the Cardinal’s chief confidant and advisor, a pragmatic and practical lawyer born to a blacksmith (important to note his non-noble family) who gains Henry’s trust and becomes the de facto chief advisor to the king.

item.title: Shalimar the Clown - Salman Rushdie (2005)
item.description: Shalimar the Clown is British-Indian author Salman Rushdie’s eighth novel, a globe trotting magical realism tragedy that reads like a thriller. The title ‘Shalimar’ comes from the famous Indian dynasty Mughal gardens of Kashmir, also the name of a character. As with many Rushdie stories, the characters themselves represent themes that Rushdie has given them, and their lives are mirrors of the history in which they live in. Rushdie generally incorporates Hindu allegory into his novels, as well as various aspects of South Asian culture and history.

item.title: Quichotte - Salman Rushdie (2019)
